content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
What's the difference between
reducing your taxable income and
reducing your actual tax bill?

objectives.description: Differentiate between tax deductions and tax credits based on how they reduce your overall tax liability.
Compute the actual tax savings from deductions and credits based on your tax bracket and situation.
Recognize common deductions and credits you may qualify for as a student or young adult.
Use tax planning strategies to minimize your tax burden while remaining fully compliant with tax laws.

terms.definition: An amount that reduces your taxable income before taxes are calculated, lowering the base on which your tax is computed.
terms.example: Mortgage interest, charitable donations, student loan interest, medical expenses

terms.definition: An amount that directly reduces your tax bill dollar-for-dollar after taxes are calculated.
terms.example: Child Tax Credit, Earned Income Tax Credit, American Opportunity Credit

terms.definition: A fixed amount based on filing status that reduces taxable income‚Äîno itemizing needed. Used by ~90% of filers.
terms.example: Single: $13,850 ‚Ä¢ Married Filing Jointly: $27,700 ‚Ä¢ Head of Household: $20,800

terms.definition: Refundable credits can result in a refund if they exceed your tax bill. Nonrefundable credits can only reduce your tax to zero.
terms.example: EITC (refundable) ‚Üí can get $ back ‚Ä¢ Child Care Credit (nonrefundable) ‚Üí only reduces to $0

leftPanel.title: Deductions Reduce Taxable Income
paragraphs: Tax deductions work by lowering the amount of income subject to taxation. This happens BEFORE your tax is calculated.
The actual tax savings depends on your marginal tax rate (tax bracket). Higher bracket = more valuable deductions.

highlightBox.text: � A $10,000 deduction in the 22% bracket saves $2,200. The same deduction in the 12% bracket saves only $1,200.

leftPanel.title: Credits: Dollar-for-Dollar Savings
paragraphs: A tax credit directly reduces the amount of tax you owe. If you owe $5,000 in taxes and have a $1,000 credit, you now owe $4,000.
This makes credits particularly powerful‚Äîa $1,000 credit saves exactly $1,000, regardless of your tax bracket.

highlightBox.text: � A relatively small tax credit can be MORE valuable than a larger tax deduction, especially for lower-income taxpayers.

layoutData.title: Standard vs. Itemized Deductions
paragraphs: You must choose one: the standard deduction (a fixed amount) OR itemized deductions (sum of specific expenses). Choose whichever is larger.
bulletPoints: Mortgage Interest: Interest on home loans up to $750,000
State & Local Taxes (SALT): Up to $10,000 in state income, property, and sales taxes
Medical Expenses: Amounts exceeding 7.5% of your income
Student Loan Interest: Up to $2,500 (even with standard deduction!)
Educator Expenses: Teachers can deduct up to $300 for supplies

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Tax Knowledge = Financial Power
paragraphs: Understanding deductions and credits can save you thousands of dollars throughout your life. This knowledge helps you make smarter decisions about:
bulletPoints: Education Decisions: Timing tuition payments to maximize education credits
Housing Choices: Understanding when mortgage interest deduction makes renting vs. buying decisions clearer
Retirement Saving: Contributing to tax-advantaged accounts for current deductions AND future savings
Charitable Giving: Strategic timing of donations to maximize deduction benefits
Healthcare: HSA contributions provide triple tax advantages

leftPanel.title: Smart Strategies to Reduce Taxes
paragraphs: Timing matters. Sometimes delaying income or accelerating deductions can result in significant tax savings.
"Bunching" deductions: If your itemized deductions are close to the standard deduction, consider making two years' worth of charitable donations in one year to exceed the threshold.

highlightBox.text: � Tax planning isn't about cheating‚Äîit's about using legal strategies to keep more of what you earn.

scenario.name: Emily: Recent Graduate Power Planning
paragraphs: Emily just graduated and started her first job earning $40,000. She paid $2,800 in student loan interest, contributed $3,000 to her IRA, and completed a certification that qualifies for the Lifetime Learning Credit.
With tax planning knowledge: Emily claims the student loan interest deduction ($2,500 max), IRA deduction ($3,000), standard deduction ($13,850), and the $1,500 Lifetime Learning Credit.
Without tax planning? She would have paid over $4,100 MORE in taxes!
